author: FinanceJedi
body: Citrix is a piece of shit. Fuck this company, fuck their outdated, clunky software, and fuck the companies that make their employees use this flaming piece of shit.

author: misspiggy123
body: My company (construction general contractor that is not down with WFH) started using Slack when this shit started to go down. We’ve since pivoted to Teams, because we didn’t want to pay for Slack’s premium version and Teams was included in our Microsoft bundle. Personally, I have experience with many of these videoconferencing systems and I would rate the ones I’ve used from beat to worst as follows: Skype (best UI IMHO), Bluejeans, Citrix, Zoom, Teams, Slack, Google Hangouts. Not that any of that really matters...bottom line is I think that Teams will get market share because it’s included in a bundle that every business has. Shorting Zoom is a no-brainer, just need to go 9-12 mos out.

author: Spuri0n
body:
I have but as you said, some of them aren't as relatable to the niche market that CSOD operates in. However, I do believe that CSOD will see better in growth in this arena than others (not necessarily Citrix, whatabeast, long after earnings again). 

I do agree this is a short term play, I am intending on jumping out when my risk tolerance hits. Hopefully this play is smart and makes a fair percentage, and I believe it will. It's nice to catch a stock before it's bull-run and I really think this has potential to do that. I am likely going to split my investment into stocks (2.5k) and slowly ease into more calls (5k total, 1.5k now) if the trend is correct. For what it is worth, this following research has given me more belief that a solid recovery is about to occur.

> Saba acquisition has provided additional insights on improving operational efficiency, which is driving further operating margin improvement. 

> Saba acqusition will not be a full tax-payer until 2023

> They believe that the Saba acquisition will cause their standalone unlevered free cash flow to be meaningfully higher than current estimations ($150M)

> AWS credits that were modeled as expenses

> Certain 2019 Capital expenditures will not be present in 2020

> "And we did see some signs of good momentum going into 2020 for Japan. But I'd say APJ was mixed because of Japan's performance."

> "we do have a plan to hit the rule of 40 in 2020 on a standalone basis and we expect to significantly exceed our original cash flow target, which was $150 million. If you recall a couple of years ago, we laid that out we expect to be meaningfully above that"

> Literally they hired, AlixPartners, a world-class consulting firm with particular expertise in performance improvement and cost optimization.

> its Q1 subscription revenue guidance calls for 10.5% y/y growth, which means that Cornerstone is planning for roughly 30% margins in 2020 (was 10% or something)

> most of Cornerstone's annual revenue is already locked in

> consolidated 2019 results suggest Saba will net roughly $250 million in annual subscription revenue for the company. Saba is also expected to "substantially increase unlevered free cash flow".

> Saba will at least increase market share in their respective markets.

Well I at least should be critical, and these are some concerns:

> They are taking on a huge $985 million term loan to finance the deal.

>layoffs that are happening across the U.S. will lower Cornerstone's billings, which could lead to a lower subscription rate given their pricing schema

However, I really believe that investors will take note when they see the free-cash flow they are generating, their improved operational margins combined with an un-modeled acquisition that represents 33% of their current revenue.

My prediction until earnings is this: $CSOD will retest $32.50 sometime by May 1. I think it lingers around $31.50-$32.50 until just before earnings where it breaks to the upside at $33.50. If earnings are a hit, maybe we see upward of $35-$37.

author: Long_term_Andy
body: I was about to ask your thoughts on Citrix (CTXS) but i remembered you're all retarded

author: Warm_Tzatziki
body:
To be fair mate you shouldn't be ashamed even if this will be wrong. That's a solid post, with good reasoning and certainly an analysis behind this. Its a very rare thing on WSB

I dont totally agree with the prediction of last Friday being the high, but we are nearing a correction. 

I think we will ride next week on the hopes of re-opening economy (which will fail - ill come to this pater) and we have some major ER coming in next two weeks. 

I think the market will still react more to general than economical data, but we see the conversion already. 

The re-opening economy expectations are very high and this wont work out as people think. Its not a light switch. First bankruptcies after this event and people start realizing there is no magic. 

There is still ink in FED printers also. 

I also think it won't be a rollercoaster downsides now, but rather a slower, but longer and heavier downfall. 

TL;DR - not a week to buy calls or puts. Maybe a moment to buy some stocks for really short term gains. And if you owe some - consider selling if the downtrend  begins. 

Also for a solid downfall we'd need a couple of days VIX being over 60 in my opinion. 

Im sitting on 12 stocks now and i might slowly move to cash gang and wait for the downfall. Although MSFT/NFLX/ROKU/BIOGEN/CITRIX are looking to perform ok

author: Warm_Tzatziki
body:
Having SAP/NFLX/BIOGEN/CITRIX/PHG stocks in my portfolio. I dont expect much surprise but thats a commutation of ER's for a 12 stock portofilo in one week. 

Gonna be a fun ride...

Maybe same with Citrix. Zoom seemed to get all the press out of the lockdown and virtual meeting stuff but Citrix has gone up almost as much.

author: Warm_Tzatziki
body:
Sooo true about options! Same here. I refuse to do it. To much loss porn I saw. 

Its a very good portfolio for me. As opposed to options there is almost no chance AMZ BRK MSFT will be worth 0. Also very little chance that if it drops it will not rebund. 

I'd sleep well with your portfolio :)

My rookie portoflio is a bit bigger but I tend not to have more than 10-12 stocks since its not manageable than for me. 

Low risk - MSFT / JNJ / PHG
Mid-risk - 3M / Biogen / Citrix / Netflix / Roku / SAP
High-Risk - Shopify / AMD / Tesla 

Percentage varies actually as im playing a bit on the earnings. 

Frankly if a leg down begins im going cash gang most likely. Hard times will come and who knows for how long

author: Warm_Tzatziki
body:
This actually is a good reply. 

Although I did not say it will not do nothing, I'm sure it will affect many stocks, turn s&p red. Sure. Big correction - not really. 

I'll elaborate and this is my opinion. I might be very wrong like I've been many times. 

I think the market now has established the winners, companies doing ok and those who are majorly affected. That's sort of a stabilization in this time. We know who is who. Who's naked and who's well dressed up. 

While im sure Airlines, Cruises, Entertainment will keep getting smashed, on the other side companies like MSFT, NFLX or Citrix should do very well. 

Some of them will be corrected. Like Netflix - this stock will be corrected. Rather later then sooner, but will get a hit. 

MSFT? Not so much I think. Theyr AzureClouding and work from home systems are market leaders. 

I would not buy BA, MGM or Bank stocks. 

I agree 200% on:

[...] we haven’t seen the downstream effect on real demand yet. Even amazon is reporting an earnings miss


Amazon is a very interesting case. While the demand on many products should make the company sales go down, on the other hand - if you think online shopping, Amazon pops up immediately. And this situation will speed up the online...ization of the world. 

I dont see a major S&P correction due to the leaders pushing this train, but some stocks will be slaughtered. For sure


I think mate we are actually on a similar page, just a different point of view and expression.

author: JDragon1
body: I'm with you on the earnings play, but I mainly see the call options volume on $32.50c 5/15 as a large bullish hedge. Still, Citrix is the closest company to Cornerstone when it comes down to it and killed expectations. The expectations on CSOD seems conservative to me and bodes confidence that expectations will be beaten as well.

author: JDragon1
body:
U/Spuri0n have you taken a look at the competitors? IBM (Kenexa), Oracle, Citrix, and SAP released their 2019 annual reports. Some of them released their Q1 earnings, too.

Oracle and IBM earn 70-80% of their revenue from their cloud based services and software. SAP and Citrix (Web-Ex) is more weighted in this area. Growth has been trailing for all of these companies, except for one: Citrix.

My favorite out of all of them, including Cornerstone, has to be Citrix. Unfortunately, that Citrix ship has sailed. It had a damn check mark recovery! Citrix seems like a safe bet to go long, but this LMS industry seems like a short term play for me. 

I'd stick with CSDO for the earnings play with a small position of $32.5 5/15 calls. I would prefer going out to June, but there is no volume.

I think I'll wait and see how Citrix behaves to decide if I want to jump in long term.

body:
>Unpopular opinion:

>This first immediate wave of jobs being lost are very low value jobs that the economy doesn't really care about much.

People on reddit really hate acknowledging this but it's the truth. Anybody not working retail/restaurant is probably still working especially if they spend their whole day behind a computer. They can pick that computer up and work from home through a VPN or Citrix. 

That's why me an CSCO going to be good frands.

author: Warm_Tzatziki
body:
Do you have AAPL stock and want to convert? Cause that would make sense. Depending on your appetite for risk (since its WSB the entry level is YOLO risk tolerance) -  MSFT is the safest option in my opinion. Not one that will moon as everyone knows how popular their solutions are, and fairly said - they are pretty good. 

I wouldn't be so sure about ANY tech stock. I think we will some corrections soon there. 

Netflix is one of the stocks I think its gonna be corrected, but not before ER. I'm actually holding Netflix stock and ready to sell as soon as its starts getting corrected. 

Oracle- yeah pretty safe. If you plan to buy this week for short term - go with Citrix. They are having ER this week. Should rise even if it doesn't beat expectations as the outlook looks good. 

Idk about IBM. Haven't analysed them recently as since 2016 they were on a decline. They might be back on corona, but didn't hear anything great from them recently. Deeper analysis recommended.

author: MustWarn0thers
body: Anyone else playing a bit of CTXS earnings? Don't care for the software but that stock chunks a few bucks at a time constantly. Volume isn't great but they're probably going to crush earnings and have good outlook for at least second and third quarter along with any business that realizes they don't need their employees working in the office even after Tecate Cancer.

author: JerseyFlashBoys
body: ROKU DOCU CTXS

author: lol__sup
body: where the fuck did zoom come from? i've worked remotely for 6 years and had client meetings on skype, webex, citrix, hangouts, join.me, who knows what other nonsense. literally never heard of zoom before the virus.

author: punctulica
blueairplane123
body: You buying telecom stocks? Citrix?

author: Spuri0n
body:
and look at how massively Citrix ran-up before earnings. This could be a run-up play, or it could continue going up past earnings. $CSOD is barely above its lows from the crash and is in a pretty good position to start its bull run. I think one of the biggest things investors are looking for in $CSOD is free cash flow, and according to the CEO:

> we now believe our standalone unlevered free cash flow will be meaningfully higher than that.

I even think this "meaningfully higher" comment, is even higher. This quote comes from before March where we learned that their activity stats are through the roof. Their subscriptions have likely gone up, which means their free cash flow has probably grown significantly. This signals to investors a place to safely park investments.

author: Long_term_Andy
body: OK those are my thoughts. I think they should fall with the market because companies that don't use it probably won't take on an additional expense. Unless of course it will allow them to keep operating. And current customers may be struggling. I worked for a car rental company that uses Citrix and IDK if that expense is big for my company but I imagine they are trying to cut costs wherever they can

author: TehSillyKitteh
body:
5/1 $175c CTXS

Fairly aggressive strike price, but I think it's achievable. Premium was pretty low when I bought in. IV is low. 

Just gotta get that big earnings pump.

author: DingleTheDongle
body:
And there is no money in tech. I worked at Kroger HQ doing tech support for their click list and scan bag go initiatives as well as their their legacy warehouse tech support. I had to learn broad technologies like command line Linux commands for store controllers, to specific technologies like zigbee network troubleshooting to citrix and Kronos server admin.

Made 14 bucks an hour and had coworkers making less than 20 after over 10 years in similar roles.

author: ejk0005
body:
I think Citrix will go up too. BUT- 

Their growth has not exploded like everyone else. Expanded their existing licensing? Yeah, I imagine so.  I say this because the shit is hardly a flip of a switch like other vendors. Azure  - yes. Nutanix  - yes. VMware - yes. Citrix - no.

The people that needed VDI and needed it immediately- they went with any of the other players first before Citrix.

author: krushdavis247
body: Anybody holding CTXS calls for the morning er?

author: mcgokey
body: Citrix earnings.
Wrong, Citrix beat earnings and revenue and tanked even before the Gilead shenanigans

author: wsbtitsup
body: Citrix dropped in an analogous situation where sales were up but outlook was generally negative due to macro outlooks. I may bail

author: Warm_Tzatziki
body:
Having in my 12 stock portfolio a freaking accumulation of ER' this week.

PHG - should do ok. Not high expectations. Their last ventilators deal and new units presented should do for a good outlook. I dont expect it to drop. 

SAP - again no high expectations. Outlook looks good so far however might reevaluate as Workday is a very solid competitor and the market demand might drop. 

Citrix - can actually turn out ok even tho shouldn't beat expectations. Quite good outlook .

Biogen - this is a long term stock. Let's see how ER plays out. Big question mark 

Netflix - should beat expectations and go up. Long term - I think its gonna be corrected but rather closer to Q2 ER  

Gonna be an interesting week....

author: Warm_Tzatziki
body:
Having SAP/NFLX/BIOGEN/CITRIX/PHG stocks in my portfolio. I dont expect much surprise but thats a commutation of ER's for a 12 stock portofilo in one week. 

Gonna be a fun ride...

author: Warm_Tzatziki
body:
I sort of really enjoy analyzing stocks and picking them and being happy with a good looking portfolio. I was on ETFs up to 80% to my portoflio and converting to stocks. I moght very well go back to this if my current actions won't result in profits. 

5% is not necessary the goal, but its what I can achieve safely with my current knowlege, skills and not gambling. 

Im still less than a year as an active investor and I think there is space for me to go up. I learned a hard lesson trying to be smarter than the market, trying to time it and basically gambling. 

The 5-10% is with priced in failures. I can reduce the wrong decisions by learning i think. I tried virtual money, but its not the same. Emotions and psychology is also a very important element and I was not really attached to my virtual dollars. 

The smartest think would be - go VOO and trade virtually, bit I've been doing it and I don't think im benefiting from it as in terms o learning. 

I've got now:

Low risk: MSFT / JNJ / Philips (all long term, not thinking about selling)
Mid risk: Roku / 3M / Biogen / SAP / Netflix / Citrix (ready to sell if needed)
High risk: Tesla / Inseego (stop profit set to get out imidiately) 

Happy with that so far. I am also constantly working on my watchlist and have stocks to convert to in hand. Or sit on cash if nothing interesting.

author: TehSillyKitteh
body: I need Citrix to post big earnings. I've got 5/1c at $175 strike.  Aggressive but in reach I think

author: whoyoufoo101
body: Interesting, yea tech is doing great, curious what Citrix tech you’re referring to? Ssl vpn? I’ll def look into it, I’m assuming you grabbed your positions early lol :)

author: Warm_Tzatziki
body:
I dont think the world has gone insane. 

People have. The amount of people shorting the market (which at this volume of shorting actually bumps the stock up) + FOMO + you really have good deals on the market. 

Depends where you're looking. Someone buying airline stock... thats crazy. 

Buying Microsoft, Roku, Citrix etc... not so crazy. 

We will see companies mooning on this crisis. We will see bubbles for sure. 

Now about FED - what do you expect them to do? All they can do is to throw money not to let the market die. Now its not a perfect option, its not even a good option, but its pretty much the only option. 

Times are insane, prople are insane, market is being just market.

author: cschmittiey
body: Street Smart doesn’t run on mac, and trying their Citrix thing, it’d only work every other time I tried.

author: raspberrysnickers
body: Citrix

author: MasterCookSwag
body:
I've never heard of a company using teams or Skype.  I've used webex, zoom, and hangouts and have worked at firms with AUM measured in the trillions as well as my current 7B firm.  One of my good friends is a lead developer for Credit Karma and uses hangouts, another uses zoom with lending tree, I've got some friends with vanguard and they even use citrix because teams blows so hard.  They're the cheapest out there.

Nobodys saying zoom owns the market.  But anyone that thinks the majority of companies with a 365 license use Teams because it's there has probably never worked a job in their life.

author: awesomface
body:
I'm completely on board with your comment. Microsoft has the fact that Teams is included in O365 but it's not exactly a direct competitor because what Zoom has always done well is just stick to what they know. Seemless and easy to use video conferencing software that just fucking works and doesn't crash when you're sharing files or changing your audio/video. I think the only way Zoom starts to fail or lose traction is if they try to expand and develop products too quickly.

The enterprise VC market has long been dominated by people like Citrix and Microsoft built on old infrastructure and demanding you buy insanely overpriced proprietary hardware/software to run it. I have seen anecdotally and won't be surprised if as companies reach their true ups and renewals, they start taking a hard look at Zoom because of the word of mouth and such a low cost to entry.

author: Owntano
body: I'm not getting into financial details, I'm thinking big picture.  Anyone in the tech industry is working remote right now and is still doing their sprints etc. Everyone is relying on MSFT, IBM (Redhat sadly), Citrix, Zoom, ServiceNow, CISCO, Google, monitoring software (I like Dyntrace - DT), Adobe, AMD, INTEL, Amazon, AT&T, VISA, VMWare... Can't stomp em!
